message_1: A cylindrical glass has a radius of 5 cm and a height of 15 cm. A spherical marble of radius 2 cm is placed inside the glass. What is the maximum possible distance of the marble from the glass? (Assuming the marble is free to move around inside the glass)
message_2:
The maximum possible distance of the marble from the glass would be when the marble is at the center of the cylindrical glass. In this case, the distance would be from the center of the marble to the inner surface of the glass.

We can find this distance by considering the radius of the cylindrical glass and the radius of the marble. The distance from the center of the marble to the inner surface of the glass would be the difference between the radius of the cylindrical glass and the radius of the marble.

Maximum distance = Radius of cylindrical glass - Radius of marble
Maximum distance = 5 cm - 2 cm
Maximum distance = 3 cm

So, the maximum possible distance of the marble from the glass is 3 cm.
